writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?
story:
It was a typical Monday morning at the FBI headquarters, with the usual hum of coffee machines and the occasional ring of a phone breaking the silence. Neal Caffrey, the master art forger turned consultant, sat at his desk, sipping his coffee and staring at the latest case files in front of him. He had been working with the FBI for a few years now, and it had been...enlightening, to say the least. Trading in his paintbrush for a badge—who would have thought? Certainly not the art world.

As he delved into the files, his mind began to wander back to his old life. The thrill of the heist, the rush of adrenaline as he created a masterpiece that would fool even the most discerning eye...it was a high he had never truly equaled, even in his current role as a consultant. But that was exactly what he was supposed to be doing—using his expertise to help the FBI catch the bad guys, not create them.

Just as he was getting lost in thought, his phone rang. It was Mozzie, his old partner in crime. Neal's heart skipped a beat as he answered, a mix of emotions swirling inside him.

"Mozzie," he said, trying to sound casual. "What can I do for you?"

"Mozzie's got a proposition for you, Neal," Mozzie said, his voice low and smooth. "I've got a job lined up, and I think you're the only one who can make it happen."

Neal's instincts kicked in, and he felt a familiar flutter in his chest. He had thought he was over this life, but Mozzie's words brought it all back. He wondered if he was just fooling himself—had he really changed, or was he just wearing a different hat?

"What's the job?" he asked, stalling for time.

"It's a painting, Neal. A rare Monet. The client wants it, and I need someone with your...particular set of skills to make it happen."

Neal's mind reeled as he processed the information. A heist. A real, honest-to-goodness heist. He felt like he was 20 again, standing in front of a blank canvas, ready to create something beautiful. But this time, it felt wrong.

"Mozzie," he said, trying to keep his voice steady. "I don't know if I can do this."

There was a pause on the other end of the line, and for a moment, Neal thought he had lost the connection. But then Mozzie spoke up.

"Neal, I know you've been doing well with the FBI. I'm proud of you. But this is a chance for us to do something big, something that will set us up for life. We can't pass it up."

Neal felt a wave of guilt wash over him. He had promised himself he was done with this life, that he was committed to using his skills for good. But the thrill of the heist was calling to him, tempting him to take one last ride.

"Neal?" Mozzie said, his voice laced with concern. "You there?"

"Yeah," Neal said, taking a deep breath. "I'm here. I just need some time to think about it, okay?"

There was a pause, and then Mozzie said, "Take all the time you need, Neal. But know this—if you say no, it's done. We're done."

Neal felt a pang of sadness as he hung up the phone. He knew he was at a crossroads, and he had to make a choice. Had he really changed, or was he just fooling himself? He looked around the FBI headquarters, at the people who trusted him, who relied on him. And he knew what he had to do.

He stood up, took a deep breath, and walked out of the office. He was going to make a call, one that would change everything.

writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.
story:
He never thought he'd see Dean again, let alone feel this strange pull towards him. It had been years since their last encounter, and Crowley had almost convinced himself that it was for the best. After all, their worlds were vastly different - he was a demon, a trickster, a master of the underworld, while Dean was a hunter, a warrior, a hero. Yet, as he watched Dean walk towards him, a mix of emotions swirled inside him. He was caught between excitement and wariness, nostalgia and trepidation.

"Dean," he said, his voice a little softer than he intended.

"Crowley," Dean replied, his eyes narrowing slightly. "It's been a while."

They stood there for a moment, the tension between them palpable. Crowley broke the silence, "I didn't know you were back in town."

"I got a tip about a possible job," Dean said, his eyes scanning the area. "But I think it's a bust. What about you? What brings you here?"

Crowley shrugged, trying to appear nonchalant. "Just passing through. Enjoying the sunshine."

Dean raised an eyebrow. "You and sunshine don't exactly go hand in hand, do you?"

Crowley chuckled, a dry, mirthless sound. "No, I suppose not."

As they stood there, the world around them seemed to slow down. Crowley felt a sense of familiarity with Dean that he couldn't quite explain. It was as if they'd never been apart, as if they'd just stepped out of a long, winding road and back into each other's lives.

The next few weeks were a blur of stolen moments and whispered conversations. Crowley found himself opening up to Dean in ways he never thought possible. He shared stories about his past, about the things he'd done and the people he'd hurt. Dean listened with a compassion and understanding that Crowley hadn't expected.

One night, as they sat on the porch of Dean's family home, sipping whiskey and watching the stars, Crowley felt a sense of vulnerability wash over him. He leaned in, his voice barely above a whisper, "Dean, I have a secret."

Dean's eyes locked onto his, a spark of curiosity igniting. "What is it?"

Crowley took a deep breath, his heart pounding in his chest. "I've been trying to change. To be better. To leave the past behind."

Dean's expression softened, a look of understanding creeping onto his face. "You're trying to rewrite the plan, aren't you?"

Crowley nodded, feeling a weight lift off his shoulders. "Yes. I am."

As the night wore on, Crowley found himself drawn to Dean in ways he couldn't explain. He'd always thought of himself as a demon, a creature of the night, but as he looked into Dean's eyes, he felt a sense of humanity stir within him.

Their first kiss was a whispered promise, a soft, gentle touch that sent shivers down Crowley's spine. It was as if the world around them had melted away, leaving only the two of them, lost in a sea of possibility.

As the days turned into weeks, Crowley found himself entwined in a life he never thought he'd have. He met Dean's family, a boisterous, loving clan that welcomed him with open arms. He attended family barbecues, where he'd flip burgers and make small talk with Dean's brothers. He even started to enjoy the sunshine, the warmth on his skin a balm to his demon's soul.

But as with all things, there were complications. Federal agents started to sniff around, looking for a lead on a string of supernatural occurrences. Crowley knew he had to keep his distance, to protect Dean from the dangers that lurked in the shadows.

As they stood on the porch, watching the sun rise over the horizon, Crowley felt a sense of trepidation wash over him. He knew that their love was worth the risk, but he also knew that he couldn't promise Dean a future free of danger.

"Dean," he said, his voice barely above a whisper.

"Hey," Dean replied, his eyes locking onto his.

"I don't know what the future holds," Crowley said, his heart pounding in his chest. "But I do know one thing - I want to face it with you."

Dean's smile was a warm, gentle thing, a promise of forever in its depths. "I want that too, Crowley. I want that too."

writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.
story:
"How did I end up on this side of the law, arguing for rules I used to break?" Neal Caffrey's thoughts wandered as he sat across from FBI Agent Peter Burke, sipping on his lukewarm coffee. It was a chilly autumn morning, and the conference room was filled with the hum of fluorescent lights and the murmur of hushed conversations.

Neal's eyes drifted to the whiteboard, where Agent Burke had scribbled down a list of procedures and protocols. Neal's stomach twisted into a familiar knot as he scanned the list, his mind racing with the endless loopholes and gray areas he used to exploit. But now, as an FBI consultant, he found himself defending the very rules he once broke.

Agent Burke raised an eyebrow, his expression a mix of amusement and incredulity. "You're telling me that, as a con artist, you used to think loopholes were your best friends, but now you're patching them up?"

Neal shrugged, attempting to play it cool despite the irony of the situation. "Hey, when you're on the other side, the rules seem a lot more... appealing."

Agent Burke chuckled, his eyes crinkling at the corners. "I never thought I'd see the day you'd be quoting the rulebook, Neal."

Neal shot him a wry smile. "Old habits die hard, but maybe they can be reformed."

Their discussion was interrupted by the arrival of a young agent, who dropped a stack of files onto the conference table. "Sorry to interrupt, Agent Burke, but we've got a new lead on the Stevens case."

Agent Burke's expression turned serious as he began to review the files. Neal watched him, his mind still wandering back to his past. He had spent years honing his skills as a con artist, always staying one step ahead of the law. But after being caught and sent to prison, he'd made a deal with Agent Burke: in exchange for his freedom, he'd use his skills to help the FBI.

It was a strange feeling, being on the right side of the law. Neal's conscience still nagged at him, reminding him of the countless times he'd exploited the system for his own gain. But with Agent Burke's guidance, he'd been slowly learning to navigate the world of law enforcement.

As they delved deeper into the case, Neal found himself growing more and more animated, arguing for proper procedures and protocols. Agent Burke watched him, a look of surprise on his face.

"You know, Neal, I never thought I'd see the day you'd be defending the FBI's reputation."

Neal grinned, feeling a sense of pride he hadn't experienced in years. "Hey, when you're on the right side, it's a lot easier to defend."

Their discussion was interrupted by a sudden burst of laughter from the back of the room. Neal turned to see a group of agents gathered around the whiteboard, staring at a particularly complex diagram.

"Neal, can you explain this to me?" one of them asked, looking at him with a mixture of confusion and amusement.

Neal hesitated for a moment, his mind racing with the intricacies of the diagram. But then, something unexpected happened. A tingling sensation coursed through his fingers as he began to explain the diagram, his words flowing easily and confidently.

It was a small moment, but it felt significant. Neal realized that, for the first time in his life, he was speaking the truth without any ulterior motives. It was a strange, tingling sensation, one that he couldn't quite explain.

Agent Burke watched him, a look of pride on his face. "You know, Neal, I think you're finally starting to get it."

Neal smiled, feeling a sense of belonging he'd never experienced before. He was still a con artist at heart, but for the first time in his life, he was on the right side of the law.

As they left the conference room, Neal caught Agent Burke's eye. "Hey, you're not going to bring this up in our next meeting, are you?"

Agent Burke grinned. "Oh, I'm definitely going to bring it up. But don't worry, Neal. I'll make sure to give you a participation trophy."

Neal rolled his eyes, laughing. "You're a real charmer, Burke."

Their banter continued as they walked out of the conference room, Neal feeling a sense of belonging he'd never experienced before. He was still a con artist at heart, but for the first time in his life, he was on the right side of the law.

writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.
story:
He stood in the dimly lit engine room, the faint scent of ozone and burned circuits hanging in the air. His mind racing, he stared at the seemingly inert console, trying to will it back to life. "Come on, baby," he muttered, his voice laced with frustration. "You've got to have a reason for this, don't you?"

Captain Kirk's voice echoed through the intercom, his words a stark reminder of the time ticking away. "Chief, we're running out of options here. If we don't get the engines online, we'll be drifting in space until...well, until we run out of air, water, and hope."

He knew the captain was right. The Enterprise had been stranded for hours, and his team had scoured every inch of the ship, searching for a cause. But every theory, every possible explanation, had been exhausted. It was as if the ship had simply...given up.

He thought back to the countless hours he'd spent in this very room, pouring over schematics, running simulations, and testing theories. He'd always been the first to admit when he didn't know something, but this...this was different. This was personal.

A faint memory surfaced, one he'd pushed aside in the heat of the moment. "Dad always said, 'Every problem has a solution, you just have to find the right angle.'"

He chuckled wryly, a hint of irony creeping into his voice. "Yeah, Dad, real helpful, considering we're stuck in space with no air, no power, and no way to get home."

Spock's calm, logical tone interrupted his thoughts. "Chief, I've been reviewing the ship's systems, and I believe I've found a possible cause."

He raised an eyebrow, intrigued. "Go on."

"It appears that the ship's energy matrix has become...unstable. The calculations are a bit complex, but essentially, it's as if the ship's energy is being...siphoned away."

He whistled softly, impressed despite himself. "Spock, you're a genius."

The Vulcan's expression remained stoic, but a hint of pride flickered in his eyes. "Thank you, Chief."

Kirk's voice cut in, his tone urgent. "Spock, we need to know if this is a fixable problem. Can we get the ship back online?"

Spock's pause was brief, but telling. "I'm not certain, Captain. But I believe we may have a chance. Chief, I need you to work with Lieutenant Uhura to access the ship's energy matrix and see if we can...re-route the energy flow."

He nodded, already moving towards the console. "On it, Spock. Uhura, can you—"

The communications officer's voice was a welcome distraction. "Chief, I'm accessing the matrix now. Hold on, I'm—"

A burst of static interrupted her words, and the console in front of him flared to life. The ship's systems began to hum, and a soft, blue glow spread throughout the engine room.

He let out a whoop of triumph, pumping his fist in the air. "Yes! We're back online, folks! Let's get this ship moving!"

The crew's cheers and shouts of excitement filled the room, mingling with the hum of the engines. As he grinned at Spock, he felt a sense of pride and gratitude wash over him. They'd done it. They'd found the solution, and they'd saved the ship.

Kirk's voice boomed through the intercom once more, his words a testament to the crew's resilience. "Well, that worked out great. At least we're not floating in space...yet. Let's get home, people!"

He chuckled, feeling a sense of camaraderie with his crewmates. They'd faced the impossible, and they'd come out on top. As he worked to stabilize the ship's systems, he couldn't help but feel a sense of awe at the incredible team he'd assembled.

In the vastness of space, it was their differences that united them. And in this moment, as they sailed through the cosmos, he knew that nothing could stop them.

writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.
story:
It was ironic, really, being accused of something I didn't do. But then again, irony seemed to be my constant companion. I sat in the conference room, sipping my coffee, as Agent Rachel Jenkins went over the details of the audit. Peter, ever the stoic, listened intently, his expression a mask of calm.

The agent's eyes, however, were another story altogether. They narrowed as she spoke, her gaze lingering on me with a mixture of suspicion and disdain. I'd seen that look before, of course. It was the same one people gave me when they found out about my... extracurricular activities.

But this was different. This was personal.

"I'm not sure what's more disturbing, Neal," Agent Jenkins said, her voice dripping with sarcasm, "the fact that you're under suspicion for forgery or the fact that you've managed to keep this under wraps for so long."

I smiled, a wry, humorless smile. "Of all the things I've been accused of, this one's almost flattering. Almost."

Peter shifted in his seat, his eyes flicking to me before returning to the agent. "Neal, you know he didn't do it," he said, his voice firm.

The agent raised an eyebrow. "Really, Peter? You're taking his word for it? After everything he's done?"

I winced, feeling a familiar sting of defensiveness. But Peter's next words stopped me cold.

"Neal, you know I trust you. And I know you'd never do something like this."

I met his gaze, a warmth spreading through my chest. It was moments like these that I remembered why I did what I did – for him, for the team, for the thrill of the chase.

But I also knew that trust was a currency I'd spent too freely. Time to earn some back.

I leaned forward, my eyes locked on the agent. "I understand you have your doubts, Agent Jenkins. But I assure you, I'm innocent. And I'm willing to do whatever it takes to prove it."

The agent raised an eyebrow, a hint of curiosity in her voice. "Oh? And what exactly do you propose we do?"

I smiled, a plan already forming in my mind. "Well, for starters, I think we need to dig deeper. Find out who really committed this forgery and clear my name in the process."

Peter's eyes widened, a hint of alarm in his voice. "Neal, that's not a good idea. We can't just go around accusing people without evidence."

I waved a hand, dismissing his concerns. "Leave that to me. I've got a plan."

The agent's eyes narrowed, a hint of skepticism in her voice. "And what exactly is this plan of yours, Neal?"

I leaned back in my chair, a wicked grin spreading across my face. "Oh, it's simple. We'll just create a little diversion, draw the real culprit out, and then –"

The agent's eyes widened, a look of horror on her face. "You can't be serious, Neal. That's reckless, not clever."

I shrugged, a mischievous glint in my eye. "Hey, when you're dealing with forgeries, you've got to think outside the box. And besides, it's not like I'm going to get caught."

Peter's face was a mask of concern, but I could see the hint of a smile lurking beneath the surface. He knew me too well, knew that I was capable of pulling off even the most impossible heists.

The agent, on the other hand, looked like she was about to have a heart attack. "Neal, you're not taking this seriously enough. This is a federal offense we're talking about."

I leaned forward, my voice taking on a persuasive tone. "Agent Jenkins, I assure you, I'm taking this very seriously. And I'm willing to do whatever it takes to clear my name and protect my team. So, are you with me, or are you going to let your doubts hold you back?"

The agent's eyes narrowed, a hint of calculation in her voice. "Fine. I'm in. But if you get us caught, Neal, you're going down alone."

I grinned, a triumphant smile spreading across my face. "Oh, I wouldn't have it any other way."

The game was on, and I was ready to play.
